oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wheat threshing equipment owned by George Whiteside of Swan Creek
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Wheat; Threshing; Threshing machines; Harvesting; Agricultural laborers; Farm produce; Harvesting machinery; Agricultural machinery & implements; Farms; Farm life; Mules
Agriculture; Wheat - Harvesting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dual photograph featuring two images of the wheat threshing equipment that was owned by George Whiteside of Swan Creek. A number of farm workers are pictured circulating between the thresher and the mule-drawn wagons of wheat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Looking Back at Tennessee Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Following the drying of the wheat shocks, thresher crews would arrive in the fields. Thresher equipment, run by tractor or steam engine would be set up. Workers would then gather the shocks into a wagon and take them to the threshing operation, where they would be fed into the machine. Threshing machines worked faster and supplied a cleaner product that old methods of treading out or flailing.
